prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Mrk 348
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Mrk 348 Band 3 absorption line study for HCN and HCO+ J(1-0).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Mrk 348 is variable and has an approximate total flux of 500 mJy in Band 3. We can detect an absorption trough of 3% at 10 sigma using 1.5 mJy pointing sensitivity. Adopting a typical line width of 500 km/s and a frequency resolution of about one tenth of the width, 40.2 mins of total observing time will be needed. We use the FDM mode of the correlator with maximum possible bandwidth (1875 MHz) and adopt a spectral averaging by a factor of 2, which places the spectral resolution in the desired range of 1 MHz per frequency channel. The spectral windows are:
baseband 1, centered at 85.5 GHz for SiO v=1,2-1 and SiO v=0,2-1 (2nd prio), baseband 2, centered at 85.7 GHz for HCN v=0,1-0, HCO+ v=0,1-0 and HNCO (v=0,4-3) baseband 3, centered at 98.59 GHz for HC3N (v=0,11-10) (2nd priority)
We aim at pointed flux measurements, without imaging and without the use of the ACA. For the detection of the absorption lines towards the nucleus, a moderate angular resolution of 2 arcseconds is sufficient, although a higher angular resolution would further improve the continuum to line contrast (filling factor).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 3C120
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: 3C120 Band 3 absorption line study for HCN, HNC and HCO+ v=0, J(1-0).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The radio galaxy 3C120 is variable and has an approximate total flux of 1.Jy in Band 3. We can detect an absorption trough of 1.5% at 10 sigma using 1.5 mJy pointing sensitivity. Adopting a typical line width of 500 km/s and a frequency resolution of about one tenth of the width, 34.8 mins of total observing time will be needed. We use the FDM mode of the correlator with maximum possible bandwidth (1875 MHz) and adopt a spectral averaging by a factor of 2, which places the spectral resolution in the desired range of 1 MHz per frequency channel. The spectral windows are:
baseband 1 centered at 86.0 GHz covering HCN v=0,1-0 and HCO+ v=0,1-0 baseband 2 centered at 87.72 GHz covering HNC v=0,1-0 baseband 3 centered at 97.8 GHz covering SO2 v=0,2-3
We aim at pointed flux measurements, without imaging and without the use of the ACA. For the detection of the absorption lines towards the nucleus, a moderate angular resolution of 2 arcseconds is sufficient, although a higher angular resolution would further improve the continuum to line contrast (filling factor).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: PKS 0528+134
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: PKS 0528+134 Absorption line study for HCN and HCO+ J(3-2) redshifted into band 3.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The quasar PSK 0528+134 is variable and has an approximate total flux of 1.Jy in Band 3. We can detect an absorption trough of 2% at 10 sigma (2 mJy pointing sensitivity). Adopting a typical line width of 500 km/s and a frequency resolution of about one tenth of the width, 30.9 mins of total observing time will be needed. We use the FDM mode of the correlator with maximum possible bandwidth (1875 MHz) and adopt a spectral averaging by a factor of 2, which places the spectral resolution in the desired range of 1 MHz per frequency channel. The spectral windows are:
baseband 1 centerd at 85.0 GHz for SiO v=0,6-5, SiO v=1,6-5, SO2 v=0,4-5 (2nd prio), baseband 2 centered at 86.8 GHz for HCN v=0,3-2, HCO+ v=0,3-2 and HCO+ v=0,3-2, baseband 3 centered at 97.62 GHz for SiO v=2,7-6 and SiO v=1,7-6 (2nd prio), baseband 4 centered at 99.0 GHz for SiO v=0,7-6 (2nd prio).
We aim at pointed flux measurements, without imaging and without the use of the ACA. For the detection of the absorption lines towards the nucleus, a moderate angular resolution of 2 arcseconds is sufficient, although a higher angular resolution would further improve the continuum to line contrast (filling factor).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 3C270
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: 3C270 Band 3 absorption line study for HCN and HCO+ J(1-0).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
3C270 (NGC4261) is variable and has an approximate total flux of 300 mJy in Band 3. We can detect an absorption trough of 5% at 10 sigma (1.5 mJy pointing sensitivity). Adopting a typical line width of 500 km/s and a frequency resolution of about one tenth of the width, 34.8 mins of total observing time will be needed. We use the FDM mode of the correlator with maximum possible bandwidth (1875 MHz) and adopt a spectral averaging by a factor of 2, which places the spectral resolution in the desired range of 1 MHz per frequency channel. The spectral windows are:
baseband 1 centered at 86.22 GHz for SiO v=0,2-1 and SiO v=1,2-1 (2nd prio), baseband 2 centered at 88.10 GHz for HCN v=0,1-0 and HCO+ v=0,1-0, baseband 3 centered at 97.40 GHz for CS v=0,2-1 (2nd prio), baseband 4 centered at 99.10 GHz for HC3N v=0,11-10, also covering SO and SO2 (2nd prio).
We aim at pointed flux measurements, without imaging and without the use of the ACA. For the detection of the absorption lines towards the nucleus, a moderate angular resolution of 2 arcseconds is sufficient, although a higher angular resolution would further improve the continuum to line contrast (filling factor).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Cygnus A
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Cygnus A Band 3 absorption line study for HNC and HCO+ J(1-0).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The core of the FRII radio galaxy Cygnus A is variable and has an approximate total flux of 800 mJy in Band3. We can detect an absorption trough of 1.9% at 10 sigma (1.5 mJy pointing sensitivity). Adopting a typical line width of 500 km/s and a frequency resolution of about one tenth of the width, 39.6 mins of observing time will be needed. We use the FDM mode of the correlator with maximum possible bandwidth (1875 MHz) and adopt a spectral averaging by a factor of 2, which places the spectral resolution in the desired range of 1 MHz per frequency channel. The spectral windows are:
baseband 1 centered at 85.00 GHz covering HCO+ v=0,1-0, HOC+ v=0,1-0 and HOC+ v=0,1-0, baseband 2 centered at 86.40 GHz covering HNC v=0,10-9, HC3N v=0,10-9, baseband 3 centered at 98.50 GHz covering SO2 v=0,3-2 (2nd prio).
We aim at pointed flux measurements, without imaging and without the use of ACA. For the detection of the absorption lines towards the nucleus, a moderate angular resolution of 2 arcseconds is sufficient, although a higher angular resolution would further improve the continuum to line contrast (filling factor).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: PKS 0743-006
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: PKS 0743-006 Band 3 absorption line study for HCN, HNC and HCO+ J(1-0).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
PKS 0743-006 is variable and has an approximate total flux of 400 mJy in Band 3. We can detect an absorption trough of 3.8% at 10 sigma (1.5 mJy pointing sensitivity). Adopting a typical linewidth of 500 km/s and a frequency resolution of about one tenth of the width, 34.1 mins of total observing time will be needed. We use the FDM mode of the correlator with maximum possible bandwidth (1875 MHz) and adopt a spectral averaging by a factor of 2, which places the spectral resolution in the desired range of 1 MHz per frequency channel. The spectral windows are:
baseband 1 centered at 90.35 GHz for HCN v=0,2-1, HCO+ v=0,2-1, HOC+ v=0,2-1, baseband 2 centered at 89.20 GHz for HNC v=0,2-1, baseband 3 centered at 102.43 GHz for C3H+ (9-8) (2nd prio), baseband 4 centered at 101.50 GHz for two SO2 lines (2nd prio).
We aim at pointed flux measurements, without imaging and without the use of the ACA. For the detection of the absorption lines towards the nucleus, a moderate angular resolution of 2 arcseconds is sufficient, although a higher angular resolution would further improve the continuum to line contrast (filling factor).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Molecular absorption line studies provide a powerful method to probe the chemical, physical and geometrical properties of the circumnuclear material orbiting the central parsecs of AGN. The presence of a molecular torus is a crucial element in the framework of the unified scheme. However, previous studies of molecular CO in AGN have often failed the detection. Here we propose to search for broad absorption lines of the high density tracer molecules HCO+, HCN for a small sample of compact and mm-bright radiosources at different redshifts. As a follow up, we plan to perform an absorption line VLBI study, for the first time at 3 mm. This ultra-high resolution imaging will allow to probe the torus on totally unexplored scales. The sources were selected based on the presence of counter-jets and/or known indicators of molecular absorption (HI, OH) at cm-wavlength as well as large HI column densities. With its excellent sensitivity, a broad spectral coverage paired with a small observing beam, ALMA is the right instrument to detect few percent absorption throughs against a few 100 mJy AGN continuum.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Onsala Space Observatory, Chalmers University of Technology
Onsala Space Observatory, Chalmers University of Technology
